text:
Much innovation is being
developed every day

to help deliver better
health care at lower costs.

But new technologies
and payment models

will not be enough
if we fail to align

the incentives of physicians,
nurses, and technicians

who make day-to-day patient care
decisions within health care
delivery institutions.

In my research I examine
why we reward clinicians
and how we reward them.

For example, health
care is increasingly

delivered by teams
of professionals,

but most physicians
are still paid

on the basis of individual
performance measures heavily

anchored to volumes
of services rendered

with very little weight
assigned to quality.

Accordingly, clinicians
don't feel properly

valued and rewarded for
their contributions.

Institutions that
intentionally leverage

a variety of mechanisms
beyond the paycheck

to reward clinicians in the
ways they want to be rewarded

are more likely to create an
environment in which they feel

valued and motivated
to deliver the best
care to their patients.
